hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: City’s steady enough. I keep to myself, mostly.
Still have my old typewriters at home. Small repairs, nothing much.
That coin mess made things rowdy in my building.
Quiet’s harder to come by these days.
As alright as it can be, these days.
I stick to restoration work. Typewriters, mostly pre-system.
That coin trouble disrupted my evenings. Hard to concentrate.
Noise carries now. Even my manual machines sound loud.
Just prefer things quiet—keeps the mind clear.
City has its moments. I manage well enough.
Restoring antique typewriters is my thing. Keeps my hands busy.
I write by hand when the machines get too loud.
These coins showing up—made everyone suspicious, harder to focus.
Someone found one in my laundry room last week.
Makes old habits feel risky, even something simple like typing.
Getting by. Been spending evenings with my typewriter collection.
I restore them, keep a handwritten journal—helps me remember a different time.
Since those coins started circulating, neighbors are restless. Hallways feel less private.
Last Thursday, I heard a coin was found right below my flat.
Couldn’t work on my Olympia—felt too exposed, had to switch to pen and paper.
Strange, how city memories surface and unsettle everything now.
Used to be I could disappear into my hobby. Not anymore, it seems.
City pretends to run smooth, but the system’s cracks show now and then.
I was an assistant for the Council once, before retirement. Now it’s antique typewriters, handwritten logs.
I mistrust electronics—my old Underwood never betrayed a secret.
Those data coins—appearing everywhere—changed even that. Someone left one near my door last week.
Neighbors started whispering. The air’s thick with suspicion again—reminds me of BCI audits.
I avoid typing after dark—any noise draws attention now. Notes stay locked away, always.
Restoration used to be comfort, now it’s almost an act of defiance.
It’s odd: the more history seeps through, the more careful I have to become.
hobby_answer: Yes, managed to source one. Quite difficult these days.
Typewriter works, though the neighborhood's restless now.
Lot of talk about those coins. Noise travels up, interrupts focus.
Hard to work with all this attention to old things.
Never thought typewriters would feel exposed.
Picked up a ribbon from a backroom vendor. Supply's irregular.
Have to be quiet about the hobby lately.
People ask pointed questions since those coins appeared.
Neighbors linger outside, searching for connections — makes privacy harder.
Used to enjoy fixing keys at night. Now I keep blinds shut.
Feels like anything old or personal draws eyes.
Got the ribbon, finally — not easy with current shortages.
Fixing the Olympia last week was jittery, too many voices in the hall.
Ever since coins turned up, folks wander around asking odd questions.
Used to get lost in the mechanics. Now, distracted by building noise.
Jotting notes by hand instead of typing. Cautious habit, old Council training.
Curious how city memories show up in coins, disrupt even small comforts.
Things aren't as private as they used to be.
Found a rare black ribbon, after searching half the district.
Last Thursday, just as I finished threading it, cries in the courtyard — more coins.
Typewriting used to clear my mind after work. Now people fear being heard.
I keep a handwritten journal, feels safer when neighbors trade rumors outside.
Miss the days when machine noise meant company, not suspicion.
Saw someone slip a coin under a door. Suddenly my repairs seemed loud.
Council never prepared us for this kind of exposure, not even under Halden.
Strange how even an old hobby gets tangled in these new disappearances.
Yes, finally — bartered for an authentic carbon ribbon last market day.
You know I collect Olympia portables? Each with a Council story behind it.
Last week, working late, typewriter clack got drowned by shouts over coin discoveries.
Neighbors argue downstairs about people vanished, then reappearing in city records.
Used to keep my hobby open, even let kids try the keys sometimes.
Now I make repairs in silence and write only in code — habit from old Council days.
People look at antique machines like they're relics of the missing.
Makes you rethink what gets recorded... and what gets erased.
Curious, isn't it? How something like a typewriter becomes suspicious with the right noise outside.
